topic: The Anglo-Saxons, Vikings, and Norman Conquest

questions.question: When did the Roman army leave Britain?
questions.explanation: The Romans left Britain in AD 410 to defend other parts of their empire.

questions.question: Which tribes invaded Britain after the Romans left?
questions.explanation: The Jutes, Angles, and Saxons invaded Britain from northern Europe.

questions.question: What modern language developed from the Anglo-Saxon languages?
questions.explanation: Modern English developed from the languages spoken by the Anglo-Saxons.

questions.question: By around what year were Anglo-Saxon kingdoms established in Britain?
questions.explanation: By about AD 600, Anglo-Saxon kingdoms were established across Britain.

questions.question: Where is the famous Anglo-Saxon burial site located?
questions.explanation: Sutton Hoo in Suffolk is the burial site of an Anglo-Saxon king.

questions.question: Which parts of Britain remained free from Anglo-Saxon rule?
questions.explanation: Wales and Scotland stayed free from Anglo-Saxon control.

questions.question: Were the Anglo-Saxons Christian when they first arrived in Britain?
questions.explanation: The Anglo-Saxons were not Christian when they first arrived.

questions.question: Who was the patron saint of Ireland?
questions.explanation: St Patrick became the patron saint of Ireland.

questions.question: Which missionary founded a monastery on the island of Iona?
questions.explanation: St Columba founded a monastery on Iona, off Scotlandâ€™s coast.

questions.question: Who became the first Archbishop of Canterbury?
questions.explanation: St Augustine led missionaries from Rome and became the first Archbishop of Canterbury.

questions.question: When did the Vikings first visit Britain?
questions.explanation: The Vikings first arrived in AD 789 to raid coastal towns.

questions.question: Where did the Vikings mainly settle in Britain?
questions.explanation: The Vikings settled mainly in the east and north, in an area known as the Danelaw.

questions.question: What was the area of Viking settlement in England called?
questions.explanation: The Viking-controlled region was known as the Danelaw.

questions.question: Who united the Anglo-Saxon kingdoms and defeated the Vikings?
questions.explanation: King Alfred the Great united the Anglo-Saxons and defeated the Vikings.

questions.question: Who was the first Danish king of England?
questions.explanation: Cnut, also called Canute, was the first Danish king of England.

questions.question: Who united Scotland under one king?
questions.explanation: Kenneth MacAlpin united Scotland under one king.

questions.question: Who led the Norman invasion of England in 1066?
questions.explanation: William, Duke of Normandy, led the Norman invasion in 1066.

questions.question: What was the name of the battle where Harold was defeated?
questions.explanation: Harold was defeated by William at the Battle of Hastings in 1066.

questions.question: What is the Bayeux Tapestry?
choices: An embroidery showing the Norman invasion
questions.explanation: The Bayeux Tapestry shows the story of the Norman invasion of England.

questions.question: What was the last successful foreign invasion of England?
questions.explanation: The Norman Conquest of 1066 was the last successful invasion of England.

questions.question: What was the Domesday Book?
choices: A survey of land and people in England
questions.explanation: The Domesday Book was a record of land, towns, and people in England after the Norman Conquest.

questions.question: Which language influenced English after the Norman Conquest?
questions.explanation: Norman French, spoken by the ruling class, influenced the English language.
